Articles.Content:
I wish I had an answer for you @azander, but I do not know why this occurs.

I stopped using KDE a few years ago specifically because it would crash when playing KSP, parts of the GUI would become unresponsive, then simply vanish, with the whole desktop becoming gradually more broken over time after having run KSP, I don't know if this still occurs.

It'd be a workaround rather than a fix, but have you tried any other desktop environments?

That I haven't tried, yet.  I have xfce and Gnome installed as well.  I'll give them a shot.

Az

I seem to be getting a lot of seg faults again. And again, the game can last hours, or seconds. Has any headway been made on this front? The last I read, it might have had something to do with Unity's internal commands tripping C. Will it be more stable if I install mono-dev? Or another mono ver? C repository?

 

Also, is there any word on an estimate for 1.2? I skimmed the forums, but couldn't find a projected date.

 

Thanks!

Linux users helping linux users

Edited August 14, 2016 by JoelleEmmily
spell check

Hello, I haven't follow all the history with the random crash but knowing that the game can at any time stop prevents me to play... I've preferred stop playing KSP, waiting stable update, play other stable game and made little work on mods that I maintain (but with the total lack of information of the future KSP release, I lost all my motivation).

KSP 1.2 is now in QA and I haven't read something about the random crash on the Devnote :'( Is KSP 1.2 will be a stable update on GNU/Linux or not? It's quite incredible to see a game always stable on GNU/Linux since I've started to play it (near 0.22/0.23) in alpha, in beta, in the first release and unstable after this.

I'm a Steam user, when KSP 1.2 will be released, I will lost access to the last stable version of KSP (please, no answer like: "make a copy of the game" ... disc format, disc failure ...). Can you add a repository on Steam for the last really stable version of KSP with Unity 4.X.

Please, don't forget your GNU/Linux players.

Thanks.
Edited August 14, 2016 by Malah
@sal_vager So... No then. Bummer.

*deleted*

Edited August 14, 2016 by JoelleEmmily
Dup post
"Never say never", there may be a way around it that'll stop KSP crashing on all three platforms, even if it means writing custom destroy() methods in c#

Oh, I have no doubt that it'll eventually be fixed, even if some bodger has to come up with some kind of patch or exception for linux. It's just a bummer that it's not now.

Besides, I bought the game when it was 7 bux, so, I can't really complain.

Edited August 14, 2016 by JoelleEmmily
because, reasons

I'm running Linux Mint 18 64bit, on a Lenovo Y50-70 with an Nvidia GTX 860M

Mint's updates gave me a new Nvidia driver the other day but didn't really seem to change the version, it's at 367.35

Since then I noticed this shading artifact around light sources, is this something I can tweak or change?

Well, you're not supposed to be able to see that

It's not shading, it's transparency, that's the texture of the light on its mesh (the octagon) and normally the dark area is transparent, there's still some translucency so the alpha channel is there, otherwise it would be black.

As you had a driver update I'd try installing the previous driver, as the new one may be interpreting the alpha layer incorrectly, also I see you're using  visual mods, it would be worth checking in a stock install in case the texture was changed by a mod.

I'm still on nvidia-361.45 as I have an older card, and I don't see this effect.

16 minutes ago, sal_vager said:

Well, you're not supposed to be able to see that

It's not shading, it's transparency, that's the texture of the light on its mesh (the octagon) and normally the dark area is transparent, there's still some translucency so the alpha channel is there, otherwise it would be black.

As you had a driver update I'd try installing the previous driver, as the new one may be interpreting the alpha layer incorrectly, also I see you're using  visual mods, it would be worth checking in a stock install in case the texture was changed by a mod.

I'm still on nvidia-361.45 as I have an older card, and I don't see this effect.

That is caused by the shadows the clouds cast in E.V.E.  The only way to get rid of that is to turn shadows off in the E.V.E. GUI by setting _shadowfactor = 0

The only other way to fix that is to remove or remodel the light texture on that tower thing and I don't know how to do that.  The same effect happens with landing gear. 

I don't find it a big deal. I spend most of my time in space anyway. 

Edited August 15, 2016 by Galileo

18 minutes ago, Galileo said:

That is caused by the shadows the clouds cast in E.V.E.  The only way to get rid of that is to turn shadows off in the E.V.E. GUI by setting _shadowfactor = 0

The only other way to fix that is to remove or remodel the light texture on that tower thing and I don't know how to do that.  The same effect happens with landing gear. 

I don't find it a big deal. I spend most of my time in space anyway. 

You know what, that makes sense. I did notice it only appeared when the clouds came over. Duh!

As you had a driver update I'd try installing the previous driver, as the new one may be interpreting the alpha layer incorrectly, also I see you're using  visual mods, it would be worth checking in a stock install in case the texture was changed by a mod.

I'm still on nvidia-361.45 as I have an older card, and I don't see this effect.

I was so used to playing stock on my old linux laptop, I didn't even think about the fact that I was running visual mods when asking for help! Thanks

That is caused by the shadows the clouds cast in E.V.E.  The only way to get rid of that is to turn shadows off in the E.V.E. GUI by setting _shadowfactor = 0

Good to know, and useful for @Eleven

Plus I just updated my driver and can confirm it's not that.

its great to see support raising and hope for more stability in future too, but if you ask me .. well .. the current version will not stop me from playing at all .. all the addons/mods do make it playable again and outweight the random crashes (wich are annoying tho but forgivable!)

just wanted to say ty

2 hours ago, LatiMacciato said:

its great to see support raising and hope for more stability in future too, but if you ask me .. well .. the current version will not stop me from playing at all .. all the addons/mods do make it playable again and outweight the random crashes (wich are annoying tho but forgivable!)

just wanted to say ty

The hidden message you write here is "It's OK Squad, you can drop unstable release for GNU/Linux players and stable release for others".

Accept an unstable release with no plan to correct it soon, isn't good for the future of GNU/Linux players... It isn't good for the game market on GNU/Linux.

On 14/08/2016 at 8:22 PM, sal_vager said:

"Never say never", there may be a way around it that'll stop KSP crashing on all three platforms, even if it means writing custom destroy() methods in c#

Windows has also these random crash? and the writing of a custom destroy() methods is planned for KSP 1.2?

Edited August 16, 2016 by Malah

7 minutes ago, Malah said:

The hidden message you write here is "It's OK Squad, you can drop unstable release for GNU/Linux players and stable release for others".

well, your reading inbetween the lines , wich doesnt exist because i just can speak for me .. cant speak for everyone else! (im just responsible for what i say, not what you understand :P)

but nonetheless, yes i didnt tried to give the intention that everyone is allowed to drop unstable releases on the GNU-gaming market (if it is a market at least .. cuz .. well GNU? .. ), you have a point there

however, i just wanted to say that it is for me acceptable, wich  might be not count for every Linux user/unix dev

glad to hear theres a 1.2 on the way, looking forward to the update (hoping the add-ons/mods play well then too :D)

Personally I'm glad we have a release on Linux, according to Steam Linux accounts for 0.81% of their users, even OS X is only 3.37%.

Squad began to support KSP on Linux in early 2013 when exporting to Linux became stable enough in Unity, while we've only really seen a lot of attention towards Linux from the major players (Valve etc) much more recently.

Fact is there's differences between the three platforms, OS X is based on Unix for example and Linux is 'Unix like' but is not the same.

This means your Windows project very likely won't just work when exported to another platform and especially when it's not run on a supported version of that platform, Unity is good but it cannot perform miracles, so the build scripts will need tweaking, things that break on one platform but not another need a good coat of looking at, and you need to cross your fingers.

But things will break, as software is updated new issues will occur, as the systems they run on are updated new issues will occur, unfortunately the only path to no new bugs (unless there's some you've not found yet) is to run one version on one machine and never change it, that's how you end up with COBOL running the banks and Windows XP in your ATM.

KSP is always being improved, so expect new bugs even as old ones are fixed.
Ubuntu 16.04, Digital Audio via PulseAudio. No sound in game. If browser plays something from youtube, after running KSP, then play stopped. We use KSP x86_64 version.

Finally had a chance to change desktop managers. 

KDE4 + Plasma (original) has the resize issues.

Gnome seems to work okay, if a big sluggish doing screen refreshes... and lots of issues with my sound card.

IceWM... don't even try, it will lock your system up hard.  It doesn't properly support the openGL video drivers and when launched, it locks up.  Tried several OpenGL programs, not just KSP to verify this.

I will test more as I can.  These were just the initial tests for each Windows Manager.

 

Az

I think I might have figured out one of the contributing factors to my game's instability, but I didn't even know it was a possibility to be a cause. Although, I could be seeing pasterns that aren't there.

It seems that when I have a particularly high load on one core, and not the others, say when Firefox is loaded and rendering something, KSP is more apt to segfult. I had thought asynchronise multi-threading would not lead to instability, but if unity is issuing FIFO free commands, it would explain a lot, and explain why this is only happening in the new multi-core optimized version. Then again, I could be talking out of nose, but, I was able to play 20 hour straight without interruption (crashing seems to make me aware of the time so I don't over play) without programs or daemons in the background.

Again, no idea if this is correct, but as soon as I opened Firefox to listen to a thing, KSP crashed in 5 minutes, but when I tried again with nothing, I played for 6 hours more; then crashed again when I opened Firefox. It could be something to do with Firefox specifically, I don't have too many intensive programs to test with that wouldn't also grind the system to a halt. I also find that after a segfualt, I get... glitched. I get like an after image of what was in video memory before the crash, like the picture of KSP's loading screen. It doesn't LOOK like an after image mind you, it's the whole and complete screen. The effect has a name, but I can't remember it.

Edited August 18, 2016 by JoelleEmmily
spell check

hmm .. smells like a flash (video?) plugin issue .. or video rendering/playbacking in background? .. strange .. i might have to test that too .. usually have Firefox open like all the time?

sometimes i can play 6 hours streight .. sometimes it crashes cuz something isnt loaded properly modwise etc (with FF open)

Edited August 18, 2016 by LatiMacciato

@LatiMacciato I agree it might be flash, but it's also happen with VirtualBox, however, with Vbox, it's hard for me to reproduce the error as the both combined, chew my system memory to shreds.

well i tend to close all (or mostly) yt video tabs .. or sites that have videos cuz FF has its issues with too many tabs of these in general (old known issue)
